raw_comment: The graph showing plots of multiple countries and their older and younger population answering one question is the world getter better with each generation. I immediately noticed that the younger generations are a lot more optimistic than the older generation. The US for example has more than 50 percent of their 15-24 year olds believing that the world is getting better with each generation while less than 50 percent of the 40  year old believe the same thing. I am wondering based on this data could the political swing of one generation also be affecting their ideas about the future. In addition, could there be a discrepancy in what the older versus what younger populations believe is better for the world. This data is important and affects both my community and I due to the fact that the optimism in a community is really important when trying to advocate for anything. The large gap presented in the graph indicates that there are major differences between what the older and younger generations believe is better for the world. That is going to cause some tensions in a community such as mine if the discussion of differences is not addressed properly. A name I would give to this graph would be: Are the Kids Ruining Everything?
ace_sentences: The graph shows answers of older people and younger people to one question.
The question is: Is the world getting better with each generation?
I noticed that younger generations are more optimistic than older generations.
In the US, more than 50 percent of people who are 15-24 years old believe that the world is getting better with each generation.
In the US, less than 50 percent of people who are 40 years old believe that the world is getting better with each generation.
I wonder if the political swing of a generation affects the ideas of this generation about the future.
I wonder if older populations and younger populations have different beliefs about what is better for the world.
This data is important to me.
This data is important to my community.
Optimism in a community is important for advocating for something.
The graph presents a large gap between older generations and younger generations.
The large gap indicates major differences between what older generations believe and what younger generations believe.
These differences may cause tensions in a community like mine.
If a discussion of these differences is not addressed properly then tensions will increase.
The name of this graph is: Are the Kids Ruining Everything?
